definition: Used when referring to someone or something for the first time in a text or conversation.
Basaltic lava forming very rough, jagged masses with a light frothy texture.
(in the UK) Amateur Athletic Association.
The noni or Indian mulberry, Morinda citrifolia. Also:the reddish dye obtained from this plant, used (especially formerly) in India to colour cotton fabrics.
Air-to-air missile.
Used as an expression of anguish, horror, rage, or other strong emotion, often with humorous intent.
(in the Bible) brother of Moses and traditional founder of the Jewish priesthood (see Exod. 28:1).
An abdominal muscle.
(in the UK) Amateur Boxing Association.
A type of nomogram in which the required value is determined by use of a ruler or other straight edge.
A large herbaceous Asian plant of the banana family, yielding Manila hemp.
Towards or situated to the rear; back.
Bycoket.
A simple device for calculating, consisting of a frame with rows of wires or grooves along which beads are slid.
In or behind the stern of a ship.
To abandon, give up, forsake.
Behave in a way that belittles or degrades (someone)
A person who, or thing which, abases.
Make (someone) feel embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed.
An inability to walk, especially in an individual who has no demonstrable sensory impairment or motor weakness; an instance of this.
Affected with abasia; of or relating to abasia.
Basking. In predicative use only.
(of something unpleasant or severe) become less intense or widespread.
A person who, or thing which, abates, especially (chiefly Law) one that abates a nuisance.
A defence made of felled trees placed lengthwise over each other with the boughs pointing outwards.
A place to which access is restricted, especially a sacred space or enclosure; a sanctuary.
A person who takes possession of land between the death of the owner and the accession of the legal heir.
Originally:the woof or weft in a web. Later also:the warp in a web. Frequently attributive, as "abb thread", "abb wool", etc.
(in the New Testament) God as father.
The office or period of office of an abbot or abbess.

A Persian silver coin (originally weighing approx. 9.33 grams) equivalent in value to two mahmudi or 200 dinars, first issued by the Safavid Shah Abbas I (reigned 1587–1629) and continuing in use until the 19th cent.; a money of account derived from this.
In Italy and Italian contexts:an abbot. Also:a priest or clergyman in minor orders; especially one without an assigned ecclesiastical duty, formerly often acting as a professor, private tutor, etc.
The building or buildings occupied by a community of monks or nuns.
A woman who is the head of an abbey of nuns.
A man who is the head of an abbey of monks.
The alphabet.
All but dissertation, used to denote a student who has completed all other parts of a doctorate.
The ritual washing of parts of the body before prayer or handling the Qur'an; = "woodoo".
= "abduct".
Take (someone) away illegally by force or deception; kidnap.
On a line at right angles to a ship's or an aircraft's length.
To endure, suffer; to tolerate. Now always with cannot. Compare "abide". informal and regional (chiefly English) after Middle English.
In bed.
To put in abeyance, suspend; to put aside.
Aloof, apart; away, at a distance.
(in the Bible) the second son of Adam and Eve, murdered by his brother Cain.
The white poplar.
An East Asian shrub of the honeysuckle family, typically having small tubular pink or white flowers.
Encourage or assist (someone) to do something wrong, in particular to commit a crime.
Regard with disgust and hatred.
In the ancient Hebrew calendar:the first month of the ecclesiastical year and the seventh of the civil year, corresponding to the latter part of March and the early part of April.
Accept or act in accordance with (a rule, decision, or recommendation)
A person who stays in a place; a dweller, a resident. Compare "abide".
To pay the penalty for (an offence); to atone for, suffer for, make amends for, expiate (a crime, one's sins, another's guilt, etc.).
Designating a response of withdrawal from or avoidance of a stimulus; characterized by or exhibiting such a response; avoidant. Opposed to  adient .
A member of a South American people formerly inhabiting the Gran Chaco region of Argentina and Paraguay.
An abyss.
A deep or seemingly bottomless chasm.
(of something bad) experienced or present to the maximum degree.
Solemnly renounce (a belief, cause, or claim)

In India:the production and sale of distilled alcoholic drinks; the duty levied on this. Also used allusively with reference to the system of managing the sale of alcohol solely through certain licensed contractors.
Remove (body tissue) surgically.
Alternation in the vowels of related word forms, especially in Germanic strong verbs (e.g. in sing, sang, sung)
Burning fiercely.
Having the power, skill, means, or opportunity to do something.
Perhaps, possibly; =  aiblins .
The bleak, Alburnus alburnus, a cyprinid fish.
Skilfully; competently.
Covered in flowers.
Below.
To differ, be out of keeping. Usually with from.
Blushing.
To wash (oneself, or a part of the body).
A member of an Algonquian people living chiefly in Maine and Quebec.
A girdle made of fine linen, used especially by Jewish priests.
An Aborigine.
On or into (a ship, aircraft, train, or other vehicle)
A place of residence; a house or home.
In or into a boiling state; at boiling point.
In the ancient Roman world:a kind of thick cloak, worn by peasants, soldiers, and others (and, as an affectation, by philosophers).
Any of various very large constricting snakes of tropical America. Also "†aboma-snake".
Situated or moving away from the region of the mouth; situated furthest from the mouth. Opposed to  orad .
Relating to or denoting the side or end that is furthest from the mouth, especially in animals that lack clear upper and lower sides such as echinoderms.
Carry out or undergo the abortion of (a fetus)
Exist in large numbers or amounts.
On the subject of; concerning.
About.
In extended space over and not touching.
Of the head-yards of a sailing vessel:in a position with only the headsails laid aback.
Archbishop.
Scrape or wear away by friction or erosion.
Abrade 2.
An embrace.
Abroad.
A shelter, a refuge.
In predicative use:full to the brim; brimful, brimming.
A highly poisonous glycoprotein present in the seeds (jequirity beans) of the jequirity or Indian liquorice, Abrus precatorius.
In or to a foreign country or countries.
Sudden and unexpected.
Acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene, a hard composite plastic used to make car bodies and cases for computers and other appliances.
Descend a rock face or other near-vertical surface by using a doubled rope coiled round the body and fixed at a higher point.
Not present in a place, at an occasion, or as part of something.
Take in or soak up (energy or a liquid or other substance) by chemical or physical action.
Wildly unreasonable, illogical, or inappropriate.
An absence of willpower or an inability to act decisively, a symptom of schizophrenia or other mental illness.
A title given to the Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church.
A West African tree which yields soft pale timber, and leaves that are used in herbal medicine.
Teeming, filled (with something); bursting out. Only in predicative use.
Use (something) to bad effect or for a bad purpose; misuse.
(of a person or animal) treated with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly.
A person who is or has been abused.
A person who uses something to bad effect or for a bad purpose.
(of a building or an area of land) be next to or have a common boundary with.
Filled with a continuous humming sound.
Alcohol by volume.
The chemical element actinium.
A tree or shrub of warm climates which bears spikes or clusters of yellow or white flowers and is typically thorny.

A former French colony established in 1604 in the territory now forming Nova Scotia in Canada. It was contested by France and Britain until it was eventually ceded to Britain in 1763; French-speaking Acadians were deported to other parts of North America, especially Louisiana.
Any plant of the genus Acanthus or (more widely) the family Acanthaceae.
A small deep-bodied freshwater fish native to Central and South America, having elongated dorsal and anal fins.
A large order (or subclass) of small arachnids which comprises the mites and ticks. They are distinguished by an apparent lack of body divisions.
A mite or tick; specifically (in later use) a mite of the genus Acarus (family Acaridae). Also (in form Acarus):the genus itself.
A purchaser of provisions; a provider or preparer of foodstuffs or delicacies; a purveyor, a caterer.
Agree to a demand, request, or treaty.
A distinctive way of pronouncing a language, especially one associated with a particular country, area, or social class.
Consent to receive or undertake (something offered)
The means or opportunity to approach or enter a place.
Give or grant someone (power, status, or recognition)
Approach and address (someone) boldly or aggressively.
(in West Africa and the Caribbean) a fritter made with black-eyed peas or a similar pulse, or, especially in Trinidad, mashed fish.
(of a benefit or sum of money) be received by someone in regular or increasing amounts over time.
Charge (someone) with an offence or crime.
A playing card with a single spot on it, ranked as the highest card in its suit in most card games.
Accidie.
A Eurasian or North American deciduous tree or shrub of a genus which includes the maples and the European sycamore.
An organic compound formed by the condensation of two alcohol molecules with an aldehyde molecule.
Of or like vinegar or acetic acid.
Of or denoting the acyl radical —C(O)CH₃, derived from acetic acid.
Any of five acetates of glycerol, which are thick oily liquids used as solvents and plasticizers; specifically =  monoacetin . Compare also "diacetin", "triacetin".
Vinegar.
Used to express a range of emotions including surprise, pleasure, sympathy, and regret.
(in Indian cooking) a type of pickle in which the food is preserved in spiced oil.
A continuous or prolonged dull pain in a part of one's body.
A small, dry one-seeded fruit that does not open to release the seed.
A person who or thing which aches.
Suffering from continuous dull pain.
In predicative use:chill; chilly.
In predicative use:that is chiming or ringing.
Having an ache in a part of one's body.
A knee-length coat buttoned in front, worn by men from South Asia.
To make the sound ‘achoo’; to sneeze.
A substance with particular chemical properties including turning litmus red, neutralizing alkalis, and dissolving some metals; typically, a corrosive or sour-tasting liquid of this kind.
Having the properties of an acid, or containing acid; having a pH below 7.
With bitterness or sarcasm.
A battle line in a military formation.
Denoting a radical of general formula —C(O)R, where R is an alkyl group, derived from a carboxylic acid.
Relating to the acinus, a small saclike cavity in a gland.
Of or relating to an acinus or acini, especially of a gland.
A small saclike cavity in a gland, surrounded by secretory cells.
A tropical West African tree which is cultivated for its fruit and has been introduced into the Caribbean and elsewhere.
A piastre. historical in later use.
American Civil Liberties Union.
The point at which something is at its best or most highly developed.
An iron-containing mineral of the pyroxene group, which occurs as dark green, pointed crystals.
A skin condition characterized by red pimples on the skin, especially on the face, due to inflamed or infected sebaceous glands and prevalent chiefly among adolescents.
An isolated point whose coordinates satisfy the equation of a particular curve, but which has no neighbouring points lying on the curve.
In a cocked fashion; (figurative and in figurative contexts) defiantly. Occasionally also as predicative adjective:cocked.
Of the compound eye of certain insects:formed of ommatidia having transparent cells below the lens, rather than a crystalline cone or a pseudocone.
"aconic acid" noun a crystalline carboxylic acid obtained by heating itaconic acid.
The fruit of the oak tree, a smooth oval nut in a rough cup-shaped base.

Originally:the plant sweet flag, Acorus calamus. In later use:any plant of the genus Acorus (family Acoraceae), the members of which are rushlike flowering plants with inconspicuous flowers, native chiefly to wetlands in Europe and Asia. Also (in form Acorus):the genus itself.
Free (someone) from a criminal charge by a verdict of not guilty.
Irregular or disorderly behaviour, intemperance; an instance of this.
Of a place:crawling (with diminutive organisms, etc.).
A unit of land area equal to 4,840 square yards (0.405 hectare)
Unpleasantly bitter or pungent.
The group or radical —C(O)CH=CH ₂, derived from acrylic acid; also called acryloyl. Chiefly attributive or as a formative element in chemical names.
Treated as plural. A former major grouping of the animal kingdom including invertebrates with no distinct nervous system.
In an arthropod:the unsegmented region at the anterior end of the body; specifically the prostomial region of an arthropod embryo.
In a bend or curve, at an angle; (figurative) awry, crookedly.
From one side to the other of (a place, area, etc.)
The star Alpha Crucis, which is the brightest star in the southern constellation Crux and the twelfth brightest in the sky.
Take action; do something.
Treated as plural. A register of transactions, decrees, proceedings, etc.; official records.
A protein which forms (together with myosin) the contractile filaments of muscle cells, and is also involved in motion in other types of cell.
A proposed unit of the intensity of solar radiation. rare.
The art or occupation of performing fictional roles in plays, films, or television.
The fact or process of doing something, typically to achieve an aim.
Engaging or ready to engage in physically energetic pursuits.
A padded jacket or jerkin worn under armour for protection.
A person whose profession is acting on the stage, in films, or on television.
Actorish.
A New Testament book immediately following the Gospels and relating the history of the early Church.
short for Australian Council of Trade Unions
Existing in fact; real.
Sharp, pointed; needle-like.
Sharpness or keenness of thought, vision, or hearing.
The ability to make good judgements and take quick decisions.
(of an unpleasant or unwelcome situation or phenomenon) present or experienced to a severe or intense degree.
An advertisement.
A high-level computer programming language used chiefly in real-time computerized control systems, e.g. for aircraft navigation.
A proverb or short statement expressing a general truth.
(especially as a direction) in slow time.

(in the biblical and Koranic traditions) the name of the first man. According to the Book of Genesis, Adam was created by God as the progenitor of the human race and lived with Eve in the Garden of Eden.
A very hard substance mentioned by Pliny and other classical writers, variously identified. Formerly also (without reference to classical writers):†a diamond (obsolete).
Of, belonging to, or characteristic of Adam; resembling Adam in nature or condition.
Moving in a quick and lively manner.
Any of various extinct prosimian primates of the family Adapidae, resembling lemurs and known from fossil remains of the Eocene period.
Make (something) suitable for a new use or purpose; modify.
(in the Jewish calendar) the sixth month of the civil and twelfth of the religious year, usually coinciding with parts of February and March. It is known in leap years as Second Adar.
In the Islamic regions of South-East Asia:custom, accepted practice.
An atom that has been adsorbed on a surface.
Dawning (literal and figurative).
Aide-de-camp.
Join (something) to something else so as to increase the size, number, or amount.
A place where people gather for conversation.
A large antelope with a mainly greyish and white coat, native to the deserts of North Africa.
Denoting an increased or enhancing quality or factor.
A number which is added to another.
A small venomous Eurasian snake which has a dark zigzag pattern on its back and bears live young. It is the only poisonous snake in Britain.
An address, especially an email address.
A person who is addicted to a particular substance, typically an illegal drug.
Especially in Italy or in Italian contexts:used as an expression of farewell. Also as noun:a parting salutation.
Make (someone) unable to think clearly; confuse.
Unable to think clearly; confused.
Cite as evidence.
(of a muscle) move (a limb or other part of the body) towards the midline of the body or towards another part.
Dead.
To make ineffective (a specific bequest in a will) by the sale or disposal of the property specifically bequeathed before the death of the testator.
To take away, remove; (Law) =  adeem . Usually in pass.

A port in Yemen at the mouth of the Red Sea; population 588,900 (est. 2004). Aden was formerly under British rule, first as part of British India (from 1839), then from 1935 as a Crown Colony. It was capital of the former South Yemen from 1967 until 1990.
A group or radical derived from adenine by the loss of one hydrogen atom.
Very skilled or proficient at something.
Stick fast to (a surface or substance)
To exhort, urge.
In Roman-Dutch law:to accept (an inheritance) as an heir or (in South Africa) a beneficiary of a will.
Exhibiting, involving, or relating to a tendency to seek out or maximize the impact of a stimulus. Opposed to  abient .
Goodbye.
(in Spanish or Spanish-speaking contexts) goodbye.
A horizontal passage leading into a mine for the purposes of access or drainage.
The innermost sanctuary of an ancient Greek temple.

The opening of or entrance into a cavity or channel (frequently with distinguishing scientific Latin word or phrase denoting the cavity or channel); especially (more fully "aditus ad antrum") the opening between the tympanic cavity and the mastoid antrum.
An adjective or adjectival unit.
Be next to and joined with (a building, room, or piece of land)
Adjutant.
Urge or request (someone) solemnly or earnestly to do something.
Alter or move (something) slightly in order to achieve the desired fit, appearance, or result.
Of a newspaper, radio station, etc.:that is without advertisements; not carrying advertisements.
A person who works in advertising.
The section of the community regarded as readily influenced by advertising and the mass media.
The administration of a business, organization, etc.
Regard with respect or warm approval.
Confess to be true or to be the case.
Mix (something) with something else.
Admix.
Joined by having grown together.
Otto Jespersen's word for:a word (typically a verb) or group of words of secondary importance in a nexus or predicative relation.
The parts adjoining an organ.
A word added to or joined to a noun, specifically an adjective.
A state of agitation or fuss, especially about something unimportant.
A kind of clay used as a building material.
A Filipino dish of chicken or pork stewed in vinegar, garlic, soy sauce, bay leaves, and peppercorns.
A Hebrew name for God.
A metre consisting of a dactyl followed by a spondee; a verse or line written in this metre.

A beautiful youth loved by both Aphrodite and Persephone. He was killed by a boar, but Zeus decreed that he should spend the winter of each year in the underworld with Persephone and the summer months with Aphrodite.
Legally take (another's child) and bring it up as one's own.
Relating to or denoting the side or end where the mouth is situated.
Love and respect (someone) deeply.
Make more beautiful or attractive.
To a lower place or position; downward, down; towards the earth. Frequently with verbs of motion, often those signifying descent, as fall, sink, kneel, etc.
That is in a doze.
Adenosine diphosphate.
In a dream. Also occasionally as adjective (in predicative use):dreaming, asleep.
A mountain slope which faces the sun.
A city in southeastern Michigan; population 21,391 (est. 2008).
(of a boat or its passengers) floating without being either moored or steered.
In predicative use:dripping.
Clever or skilful.
In a drooping position or condition. Also as adjective:that droops; drooping with something.
(of a solid) hold (molecules of a gas or liquid or solute) as a thin film on the outside surface or on internal surfaces within the material.
‘I am here’ (used to indicate the speaker is present). Hence as noun:this statement as an answer in a roll-call, etc.
A person who is fully grown or developed.
Scorched; burnt.
Transfer (heat or matter) by the flow of a fluid, especially horizontally in the atmosphere or the sea.

To arrive, to come (to), especially at a significant juncture; (especially of something immaterial) to become a feature of or bear upon a situation, matter, etc., without being essential to it; to be added incidentally or as an adjunct.
The arrival of a notable person or thing.

A word or phrase that modifies or qualifies an adjective, verb, or other adverb or a word group, expressing a relation of place, time, circumstance, manner, cause, degree, etc. (e.g., gently, quite, then, there).
An advertisement.
Guidance or recommendations offered with regard to prudent future action.
Offer suggestions about the best course of action to someone.
A dispatch boat; =  aviso . historical in later use.
To summon (a legal action) from a lower court to a higher court, especially the papal Court of Rome. Compare "advocate", "advocation".
(as written abbreviation) an advertisement.
A tool similar to an axe, with an arched blade at right angles to the handle, used for cutting or shaping large pieces of wood.
Auto-exposure.
Of or relating to an aecium; characterized by the presence of aecia; productive of aeciospores.

A fruiting body produced on the mycelium of a rust fungus at a particular stage in its life cycle (especially, in heteroecious species, that occurring on an alternate host), within which aeciospores are produced.

A large and widespread genus of small mosquitoes (family Culicidae) including several vectors of human disease, notably Aedes aegypti, the principal carrier of yellow fever. Also (in form aedes):a mosquito of this genus (more fully "aedes mosquito").
Either of two (later four) Roman magistrates responsible for public buildings and originally also for the public games and the supply of corn to the city.
Relating to the region comprising the Aegean Sea and its coasts and islands.
A note certifying that a student is aeger.
The protection, backing, or support of a particular person or organization.

A Trojan leader, son of Anchises and Aphrodite, and legendary ancestor of the Romans. When Troy fell to the Greeks he escaped and after wandering for many years eventually reached Italy. The story of his voyage is recounted in Virgil's Aeneid.
A Latin epic poem in twelve books by Virgil which relates the travels and experiences of Aeneas after the fall of Troy.
Of or relating to Aeolia or to the Aeolians or their language; Aeolian.
A marine nudibranch mollusc of the suborder Aeolidacea, characterized by club-shaped cerata on the dorsal side of the body.
The god of the winds.
An indefinite and very long period of time.
Of or relating to an aeon; lasting an aeon, age-long.
Annual equivalence rate, the notional rate of interest on loans or credit payable if the interest was paid and added each year.
Introduce air into (a material)
Of or belonging to the air; aerial; (hence) ethereal, spiritual, incorporeal, insubstantial.
Existing, happening, or operating in the air.
A large nest of a bird of prey, especially an eagle, typically built high in a tree or on a cliff.
To introduce air into (now especially soil or turf); = "aerate".
Aeronautical.
A microorganism which grows in the presence of air or requires oxygen for growth.
The patina that copper and brass acquire with age; verdigris. Occasionally more widely:an analogous coating on any metal.
The Norse gods and goddesses collectively, including Odin, Thor, and Balder.

(6th century BC), Greek storyteller. The moral animal fables associated with him were probably collected from many sources, and initially communicated orally. Aesop is said to have lived as a slave on the island of Samos.
An age; eternity.
Audio frequency.
In a weakened or enfeebled state; tired, fatigued; weak and dizzy; close to losing consciousness; faint.
At or to a distance.
A tall West African hardwood tree with a characteristic shape resembling a pagoda.
Air Force Base.
To frighten, terrify; to make afraid.
Afraid.
The wind that blows from the south-west, especially considered as originating in Africa.
An event or sequence of events of a specified kind or that has previously been referred to.
Have an effect on; make a difference to.

To determine, decide, assess; (Law) to fix or settle the amount of (a fine or amercement), typically by adjusting a generally prescribed penalty according to the particular circumstances of an offender and his or her offence; to settle the amount to be paid by (a person); to perform this task for (a certain community or region).
To be proper, fitting, or appropriate. In later use frequently in "as affeirs":as is appropriate; so as to suit. Frequently with to (also for).
Allowing for or preserving parallel relationships.
State emphatically or publicly.
Stick, attach, or fasten (something) to something else.
A flow of something, especially water or air.
Have enough money to pay for.
An instance of group fighting in a public place that disturbs the peace.
(Chiefly in pass.). Christian Church. To baptize (a person) by affusion.
A native or inhabitant of Afghanistan, or a person of Afghan descent.
To or at a distance.
On fire; burning.
In flames; burning.
Bursting with activity; full of intense excitement.
Floating in water; not sinking.
In or into a flowing state, so as to flow.
In predicative use:flushed; blushing.
In predicative use:foaming; covered with or full of foam.
Of a lens or other optical system:that transfers an image without bringing it to a focus, i.e. so that rays entering parallel emerge parallel; relating to or constituting such a system.
In preparation or progress; happening or beginning to happen.
Before.
Into conflict or difficulty with.
Feeling fear or anxiety; frightened.
(in Arabian and Muslim mythology) a powerful jinn or demon.
In a new or different way.
In a fretted state; fretting.
A native or inhabitant of Africa, especially a black African; = "African".
The second largest continent, a southward projection of the Old World land mass divided roughly in two by the equator and surrounded by sea except where the Isthmus of Suez joins it to Asia.
A member of a Pashto-speaking people inhabiting the mountainous region between Pakistan and Afghanistan.
A thick hairstyle consisting of very tight curls that sticks out all round the head, like the natural hair of some black people.
In front. Now chiefly in "afront of":= sense B.
Frowning.
A kind of Persian rug or small carpet handwoven by nomads of the Afshar tribe in south-east Iran.
At, near, or towards the stern of a ship or tail of an aircraft.
In the time following (an event or another period of time)
The sweet course following the main course of a meal; pudding.
Especially in Latin America:= "foot and mouth disease".
(in Muslim countries, especially under the Ottoman Empire) a military commander or official.
Another time; once more.
A headband worn by Bedouin Arab men to keep the keffiyeh in place.
An image, representation, or emblem; specifically the image on a seal.
An Old World lizard with a large head and a long tail, typically showing a marked difference in colour and form between the sexes.
The plants belonging to the former taxonomic division Cryptogamia ; the cryptogamous plants collectively (erroneously believed to have no sexual organs).
The grey-winged trumpeter, Psophia crepitans, a bird native to rainforests in northern South America.
Absence of marriage; the state or condition of being unmarried. Also:lack of acknowledgement of, or opposition to, the institution of marriage.
Asexual; reproducing asexually.
A lizard of the agama family (Agamidae ).
(of a person's mouth) wide open in surprise or wonder.
A gelatinous substance obtained from certain red seaweeds and used in biological culture media and as a thickener in foods.
A fungus with a fruiting body that resembles a mushroom, having a convex or flattened cap with gills on the underside.
In a gasping condition. Also as predicative adjective:gasping, eager.
An ornamental stone consisting of a hard variety of chalcedony (quartz), typically banded in appearance.
Of the nature of, containing, or resembling agate.
A succulent plant with rosettes of narrow spiny leaves and tall flower spikes, native to the southern US and tropical America.
In a gazing attitude; in a staring or wondering manner. Frequently with sit, stand. Also as predicative adjective:gazing, staring, especially in an enthralled, wondering, or bewildered state.
A large West African hardwood tree, Gossweilerodendron balsamiferum (family Fabaceae (Leguminosae)). Also:the pale-coloured, lightweight timber of this tree, used especially for furniture.
The length of time that a person has lived or a thing has existed.
Having lived for a specified length of time; of a specified age.
In the manner of an old person.
The process of growing old.
Prejudice or discrimination on the grounds of a person's age.
Characterized by or showing prejudice or discrimination on the grounds of a person's age.
A business or organization providing a particular service on behalf of another business, person, or group.
A list of items to be discussed at a formal meeting.
Nitrogen trichloride (NCl ₃) used as an additive to bleach and artificially age flour.
A person who acts on behalf of another person or group.
A heap of stones and earth, an earthwork, mound, or embankment; (Archaeology) the raised rampart of a Roman camp; the raised part of a Roman road or causeway, with ditches on either side.
A type of highly-prized playing marble made of agate or variegated glass resembling agate.
A substance which forms the material of certain kinds of bead used in West Africa. Chiefly in "aggry bead":a type of variegated glass bead found especially in Ghana.
Aggressive, violent behaviour.
Filled with horror or shock.
Able to move quickly and easily.
The process of growing old.
The percentage charged on the exchange of one currency, or one form of money, into another that is more valuable.
Take in and feed (livestock) for payment.
In predicative use:glaring.
Gleaming.
Askew; awry.
A metal or plastic tube fixed tightly round each end of a shoelace.
In predicative use:glinting.
Glowing.
The speech sound of ‘ng’ as in thing, a velar nasal consonant represented by the symbol /ŋ/ in the International Phonetic Alphabet.
A name used instead of or in addition to a person's ordinary given name and surname; a byname.
A person descended from the same male ancestor as another specified or implied person, especially through the male line.
The Eastern dialect of Tocharian (an extinct Indo-European language):= "Tocharian A".
Recognize the existence of.
Before the present; earlier (used with a measurement of time)

Crete played an important role in the Greek struggle for independence from the Turks in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, becoming administratively part of an independent Greece in 1913.

Wound or injure (a person or animal) so that part of the body is permanently damaged.
Chief in size or importance.

A state in the north-eastern US, on the coast of the Atlantic Ocean; population 1,316,456 (est. 2008); capital, Augusta. Visited by John Cabot in 1498 and colonized by England in the 17th and 18th centuries, it became the 23rd state of the US in 1820.
More than anything else.
A French style of bookbinding with elaborate gold tooling, used for some of the books in the library of Thomas Mahieu.
(in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland) the head of a town, borough, or county council, elected by council members and generally having purely ceremonial duties.
The yellow edible fruit of a North American passion flower.
The chief municipal officer of a French town or city; (also) the chief municipal officer of one of the arrondissements or districts of Paris.
In France:a town hall; a public building housing the municipal offices of a town or arrondissement and often also serving as the official residence of the mayor.

Any of various white-rayed species of chamomile (genus Anthemis and perhaps allied genera), chiefly weeds of cultivated ground; especially (also more fully "stinking maythe") stinking chamomile, Anthemis cotula. Also:any of several other white-rayed plants of the family Asteraceae (Compositae); especially ox-eye daisy, Leucanthemum vulgare (also "†white maythe").
A Central American cereal plant that yields large grains (corn or sweetcorn) set in rows on a cob. The many varieties include some used for stockfeed and corn oil.
In Spain and Spanish-speaking countries:a woman who dresses gaily; a pretty young woman; (in early use sometimes) specifically †one from a lower social class (obsolete).
The parliament of various North African and Middle Eastern countries, especially Iran.

A West Indian shrub, Picramnia antidesma (family Simaroubaceae); (also) a medicinal preparation of the bark of this plant, formerly used to treat fevers, venereal diseases, and colic (more fully "majo bitters").
Important, serious, or significant.
A member of a North American Indian people, inhabiting Cape Flattery in north-west Washington State.
A poet or bard.
A mythical crocodile or other sea-animal, variously represented in Indian art; (in Indian contexts) the equivalent of Capricorn in the signs of the zodiac.

Cosmetics such as lipstick or powder applied to the face, used to enhance or alter the appearance.

A former country in SE Asia, consisting of the southern part of the Malay Peninsula and some adjacent islands (originally including Singapore), now forming the western part of the federation of Malaysia and known as West Malaysia.

A country of south central Africa, in the Great Rift Valley; population 17,200,000 (estimated 2015); official languages, English and Nyanja; capital, Lilongwe.

Of or relating to one of the four Sunni schools of Islamic law, founded in the 8th cent. and based on the teachings of Mālik ibn Anas, now prevalent mainly in western and northern Africa. Also absol.:the school itself.
A person who holds the doctrine of malism.
A mop; a bundle of rags fastened to the end of a stick, especially for cleaning out a baker's oven. regional in later use.

A soft, crumbly chalky rock, or the fertile loamy soil produced as it weathers.

An island country in the central Mediterranean, about 100 km (60 miles) south of Sicily; population 419,000 (estimated 2015); official languages, Maltese and English; capital, Valletta.
Mixed with malt or a malt extract.

Smelling or tasting of malt.

A plant of the genus Malus (family Rosaceae), which consists of deciduous trees and shrubs grown ornamentally and for their fruit (apples and crab apples) in the temperate zones of both hemispheres; (in form Malus) the genus itself.

A mallow; specifically a plant of the dicotyledonous genus Malva, of the family Malvaceae, the members of which are found chiefly in Europe and temperate Asia and are characterized by having an epicalyx of three bracts enclosing the calyx and one-seeded nutlets arranged in a flat whorl round a central axis. Also (in form Malva):the genus itself.

(A) A money of account used in various parts of western Europe between the 8th and 12th centuries, and in England equivalent to thirty silver pence, two and a half twelve-pence shillings, or six five-pence shillings. Also:(the name of) a coin of this value. (b) A unit of weight (especially of gold) equivalent to the weight of thirty silver pence.

Its period of greatest importance was from the late 19th to the mid 18th centuries BC; the vast palace of the last king, Zimri-Lim, has yielded an archive of 25,000 cuneiform tablets, which are the principal source for the history of northern Syria and Mesopotamia at that time.

Mother of Jesus; known as the (Blessed) Virgin Mary, or St Mary, or Our Lady. According to the Gospels she was a virgin betrothed to Joseph and conceived Jesus by the power of the Holy Spirit. She has been venerated by Catholic and Orthodox Churches from the earliest Christian times. Feast days, 1 January (Roman Catholic Church), 25 March (Annunciation), 15 August (Assumption), 8 September (Nativity), 8 December (Immaculate Conception).

Son of Tantalus, brother of Niobe, and father of Atreus. He was killed by his father and served up as food to the gods, but only one shoulder was eaten, and he was restored to life with an ivory shoulder replacing the one that was missing.

An island of Malaysia, situated off the west coast of the Malay Peninsula. In 1786 it was ceded to the East India Company as a British colony by the sultan of Kedah. Known as Prince of Wales Island until 1867, it united with Malacca and Singapore in a union of 1826, which in 1867 became the British colony called the Straits Settlements. It joined the federation of Malaya in 1948.

The male genital organ of higher vertebrates, carrying the duct for the transfer of sperm during copulation. In humans and most other mammals it consists largely of erectile tissue and is used also for urination.
A person, such as a clerk, who was employed to write by hand on behalf of others.

A former country in south-western Asia, now called Iran. The ancient kingdom of Persia became the domain of the Achaemenid dynasty in the 6th century BC. Under Cyrus the Great, Persia became the centre of a powerful empire that included western Asia, Egypt, and parts of eastern Europe; it was eventually overthrown by Alexander the Great in 330 BC. The country was conquered by Muslim Arabs between AD 633 and 651. It was renamed Iran in 1935.

Also (partly by confusion):any of several related trees, especially the pequi, C. brasiliense.

The practice of attacking and robbing ships at sea.

Each of two unsaturated, heterocyclic compounds having the formula C ₅ H ₆ O, whose molecules have a six-membered ring consisting of five carbon atoms and one oxygen atom with two double bonds between carbon atoms; specifically γ-pyran. Also:a bobbin or reel with yarn wound on it; a reel of thread or cotton.

A city in west central Italy, in Tuscany, on the River Arno; population 87,398 (2008). It is noted for the ‘Leaning Tower of Pisa’, a circular bell tower which leans about 5 m (17 ft) from the perpendicular over its height of 55 m (181 ft).

Inclined to or characterized by quackery.

A stone or metal platform lying alongside or projecting into water for loading and unloading ships.
A shallow drinking cup, typically made of wood and having two handles.
A small short-tailed Old World game bird resembling a tiny partridge, typically having brown camouflaged plumage.
Attractively unusual or old-fashioned.
(especially of the earth) shake or tremble.

A member of the Religious Society of Friends, a Christian movement founded by George Fox c.1650 and devoted to peaceful principles. Central to the Quakers' belief is the doctrine of the ‘Inner Light’, or sense of Christ's direct working in the soul. This has led them to reject both formal ministry and all set forms of worship.
A quality or property as perceived or experienced by a person.
The internal and subjective component of sense perceptions, arising from stimulation of the senses by phenomena.
An uneasy feeling of doubt, worry, or fear, especially about one's own conduct; a misgiving.
Qualmish.
A semi-public administrative body outside the civil service but receiving financial support from the government, which makes senior appointments to it.
short for quantitative analyst
A member of a North American people of the Arkansas River region, now living mainly in north-eastern Oklahoma.
Irish form of queer (sense 1 of the adjective)

Any of a number of subatomic particles carrying a fractional electric charge, postulated as building blocks of the hadrons. Quarks have not been directly observed but theoretical predictions based on their existence have been confirmed experimentally.
Originally:a large brick or tile, especially a curved firebrick. Now specifically:a refractory channel in the wall of a furnace, boiler, etc., through which the flame of a burner passes.
A place, typically a large, deep pit, from which stone or other materials are or have been extracted.
A unit of liquid capacity equal to a quarter of a gallon or two pints, equivalent in Britain to approximately 1.13 litres and in the US to approximately 0.94 litre.
A size of book page resulting from folding each printed sheet into four leaves (eight pages).

A hard mineral consisting of silica, found widely in igneous and metamorphic rocks and typically occurring as colourless or white hexagonal prisms. It is often coloured by impurities (as in amethyst, citrine, and cairngorm).

A massive and extremely remote celestial object, emitting exceptionally large amounts of energy, and typically having a starlike image in a telescope. It has been suggested that quasars contain massive black holes and may represent a stage in the evolution of some galaxies.
Reject as invalid, especially by legal procedure.
A pimple, a pustule; a small boil. Now English regional (chiefly midlands).
(of a person's voice) shake or tremble in speaking, typically through nervousness or emotion.
A quagmire; (occasionally) marshy ground. Also more fully "†quawmire".
The black-crowned night heron, Nycticorax nycticorax, which has a deep, hoarse call.
A dense growth of bushes; a thicket. Also:a patch of untillable land characterized by such thickets.
An impudent or badly behaved girl or woman.
Nauseous; feeling sick.

A heavily forested province in eastern Canada; population 7,546,131 (2006). It was settled by the French in 1608, ceded to the British in 1763, and became one of the original four provinces in the Dominion of Canada in 1867. The majority of its residents are French-speaking and it is a focal point of the French-Canadian nationalist movement, which advocates independence for Quebec. French name Québec /kebɛk/.
The female ruler of an independent state, especially one who inherits the position by right of birth.
A borough of New York City, at the western end of Long Island; population 2,225,200 (est. 2006).
Strange; odd.
The wood pigeon, Columba palumbus. Formerly also "†queest-dove".
A young cow, especially (formerly always) before it has had a calf; a heifer.
To quell, quash; = "squelch".
A brownish weaver bird found in Africa, the male of which has either a black face or a red head.
Put an end to (a rebellion or other disorder), typically by the use of force.
Satisfy (one's thirst) by drinking.
A question, especially one expressing doubt or requesting information.
A simple hand mill for grinding corn, typically consisting of two circular stones, the upper of which is rotated or rubbed to and fro on the lower one.
A long or arduous search for something.
A line or sequence of people or vehicles awaiting their turn to be attended to or to proceed.
A person waiting in a queue.
A jibe, a taunt; a quip. Compare "quibble".
A baked flan or tart with a savoury filling thickened with eggs, usually eaten cold.
Moving fast or doing something in a short time.
One pound sterling.
An unknown or unspecified individual; somebody.
Making little or no noise.
A piece of hair brushed upwards and backwards from a man's forehead.
Of, relating to, or resembling a quill or quills.
A warm bed covering made of padding enclosed between layers of fabric and kept in place by lines of stitching, typically applied in a decorative design.
A woman's genitals.
More fully "quina bark":cinchona bark; (also) the bark of various other trees having similar medicinal properties.
A hard, acid pear-shaped fruit used in preserves or as flavouring.
To move, stir, make a slight noise; to start, flinch.
A historic industrial city in eastern Massachusetts, on Boston Harbor, southeast of Boston, a shipbuilding center; population 92,339 (est. 2008).
A kind of goose (or duck), variously identified with the greylag, Anser anser, the brent goose, Branta bernicla, and the goldeneye, Bucephala clangula. Also "†quink-goose".
A plant of the goosefoot family found in the Andes, where it was widely cultivated for its edible starchy seeds prior to the introduction of Old World grains.
Inflammation of the throat, especially an abscess in the region of the tonsils.
(in piquet) a sequence of five cards of the same suit. A run of ace, king, queen, jack, and ten is a quint major and one of jack, ten, nine, eight, and seven a quint minor.
(in Spain, Portugal, and Latin America) a large house in the country or on the outskirts of a town.
The fifth of eight parrying positions.
A card game resembling pontoon, in which the object is to acquire cards with a face value totalling fifteen points, or to come as near as possible to that number without exceeding it.
A witty remark.
=  quippish .
An ancient Inca device for recording information, consisting of variously coloured threads knotted in different ways.
Four sheets of paper or parchment folded to form eight leaves, as in medieval manuscripts.
(Of a book, manuscript, etc.) consisting of quires, in quires; (of paper) folded or able to be folded in a quire.
A peculiar aspect of a person's character or behaviour.
Having or characterized by peculiar or unexpected traits or aspects.
A coil; a twist or curl, often as decoration.
A short-handled riding whip with a braided leather lash.
Asked by a person giving away a particular object:‘who wants this?’.
Mean, wretched; destitute; (later also) queer, peculiar; unwell.
To act as a quisling; to betray one's country, especially by collaborating with an occupying enemy.
Leave (a place), usually permanently.
To the utmost or most absolute extent or degree; absolutely; completely.
The capital of Ecuador; population 1,579,200 (est. 2008). It is situated in the Andes just south of the equator, at an altitude of 2,850 m (9,350 ft).
(of two people) on even terms, especially because a debt or score has been settled.
Tremble or shake with a slight rapid motion.
A test of knowledge, especially as a competition between individuals or teams as a form of entertainment.
Inquisitive.
To the extent of, as regards, with respect to.
Prison.
An external angle of a wall or building.
A ring of iron, rope, or rubber thrown in a game to encircle or land as near as possible to an upright peg.
A small short-tailed wallaby with a short face, round ears, and some tree-climbing ability, native to Western Australia.
To tremble, wriggle, writhe; to throb, pulsate, palpitate. English regional in later use.
The minimum number of members of an assembly or society that must be present at any of its meetings to make the proceedings of that meeting valid.
A fixed share of something that a person or group is entitled to receive or is bound to contribute.
Repeat or copy out (words from a text or speech written or spoken by another person)
A person who is quoted.
A person who quotes or uses quotations, especially habitually.
Said (used only in first and third person singular before the subject)
Used with contemptuous, ironic, or sarcastic force after repeating words said by someone else:‘he said?’, ‘she said?’; (hence) ‘indeed!’.
A quantity considered in proportion to a larger amount of which it forms part; a share, a proportion.
A monetary unit of Saudi Arabia, equal to one twentieth of a rial.
Recto.

The sun god, the supreme Egyptian deity, worshipped as the creator of all life and typically portrayed with a falcon's head bearing the solar disc. From earliest times he was associated with the pharaoh.

Originally (during the 18th cent.):a council or assembly, especially in a Dutch-speaking region of South Africa; specifically (usually with capital initial) the legislative assembly of any one of the former Boer republics (now historical). Subsequently (specifically among Afrikaans speakers):any council or board.
Any of various types of stony or gravelly subsoil; rubble, gravel.
The capital of Morocco, an industrial port on the Atlantic Coast; population 1,787,300 (est. 2009). It was founded as a military fort in the 12th century by the Almohads.
A step-shaped recess cut along the edge or in the face of a piece of wood, typically forming a match to the edge or tongue of another piece; a rebate.
A Jewish scholar or teacher, especially one who studies or teaches Jewish law.
A gregarious burrowing plant-eating mammal, with long ears, long hind legs, and a short tail.
A disorderly crowd; a mob.
In the Soviet Union:a school preparing workers for entry to higher education.
(in South Asia) the grain crop sown in September and reaped in the spring.
Of or relating to rabies or animals affected with rabies.
Having or proceeding from an extreme or fanatical support of or belief in something.
A contagious and fatal viral disease of dogs and other mammals, transmissible through the saliva to humans and causing madness and convulsions.
A competition between runners, horses, vehicles, etc. to see which is the fastest in covering a set course.
A flower cluster with the separate flowers attached by short equal stalks at equal distances along a central stem. The flowers at the base of the central stem develop first.
An animal or means of transport bred or designed for racing.
A hunting dog which pursues its prey by scent.
Also with capital initial. A light tan colour (originally and chiefly as a shade of face powder).
A stem of a plant, especially a grass, bearing flower stalks at short intervals.
Lively, entertaining, and typically sexually titillating.
Relating to race.
Prejudice, discrimination, or antagonism directed against someone of a different race based on the belief that one's own race is superior.
A person who shows or feels discrimination or prejudice against people of other races, or who believes that a particular race is superior to another.
A framework, typically with rails, bars, hooks, or pegs, for holding or storing things.
A person who racks wine or other liquor.
A bat with a round or oval frame strung with catgut, nylon, etc., used especially in tennis, badminton, and squash.
Of an emotion or action, etc.:bold, rash, crude; (of speech) rough, blunt; (of things) sturdy, robust.
A radar beacon that can be identified and located by its response to a specific radar signal.
Radian(s).
(in the UK) Royal Academy of Dramatic Art.
A system for detecting the presence, direction, distance, and speed of aircraft, ships, and other objects, by sending out pulses of radio waves which are reflected off the object back to the source.
A large raft; (Military) a floating artillery unit.
Of or arranged like rays or the radii of a circle; diverging in lines from a common centre.
A unit of measurement of angles equal to about 57.3°, equivalent to the angle subtended at the centre of a circle by an arc equal in length to the radius.
The transmission and reception of electromagnetic waves of radio frequency, especially those carrying sound messages.
A swollen pungent-tasting edible root, especially a variety which is small, spherical, and red, and eaten raw with salad.
The chemical element of atomic number 88, a rare radioactive metal of the alkaline earth series. It was formerly used as a source of radiation for radiotherapy.
A straight line from the centre to the circumference of a circle or sphere.
The base of a system of numeration.
Under the feudal system:=  radknight .
A dome or other structure protecting radar equipment and made from material transparent to radio waves, especially one on the outer surface of an aircraft.
The chemical element of atomic number 86, a rare radioactive gas belonging to the noble gas series.
(in a mollusc) a structure of tiny teeth used for scraping food particles off a surface and drawing them into the mouth.
A series of bursts of gunfire.
Worthless material; trash, rubbish, refuse. Also occasionally:miscellaneous material, odds and ends.
In square-rigged vessels:a small sail set above the skysail.
A palm tree native to tropical Africa and Madagascar, with a short trunk and leaves which may be up to 18 m (60 feet) long.
A means of raising money by selling numbered tickets, one or some of which are subsequently drawn at random, the holder or holders of such tickets winning a prize.
A flat buoyant structure of timber or other materials fastened together, used as a boat or floating platform.
A beam forming part of the internal framework of a roof.
Of a place or time, or of the weather:damp and cold, bleak.
A piece of old cloth, especially one torn from a larger piece, used typically for cleaning things.
(in Indian classical music) each of the six basic musical modes which express different moods in certain characteristic progressions, with more emphasis placed on some notes than others.
A bag in which scraps of fabric and old clothes are kept for use.
Violent uncontrollable anger.
A person or thing that rages.
(of cloth or clothes) old and torn.
Ragged.
A groove cut in stone, especially on a wall to receive a sheet of glass, lead, the edge of a roof, etc.
Showing rage.
Having or denoting sleeves that continue in one piece up to the neck of a garment, without a shoulder seam.
=  raggle .
A person who collects or deals in rags, old clothes, and other items.
A highly seasoned dish of small pieces of meat stewed with vegetables.
Untidy, disorganized, or incongruously varied in character.
Having an edge with oblique notches like a row of sawn-off branches.
A cheer of encouragement or approval.
In Persia (now Iran) and India:a person who guards roads for a fee; a toll-collector. Also occasionally as a mass noun.
Each of the lines in which light (and heat) may seem to stream from the sun or any luminous body, or pass through a small opening.
A subject of the Ottoman Empire (especially a non-Muslim) who is not a member of the ruling class, and is therefore liable to pay a poll tax.
A rapid surprise attack on an enemy by troops, aircraft, or other armed forces.
A person who attacks an enemy in their territory; a marauder.
Having rays of a specified number or kind.
In South Asia:a peasant, husbandman, or cultivating tenant.
A bar or series of bars fixed on upright supports or attached to a wall or ceiling, serving as part of a barrier or used to hang things on.
The condensed moisture of the atmosphere falling visibly in separate drops.
An irrigation device which delivers a rain-like spray.
(of weather, a period, or an area) having or characterized by considerable rainfall.
A textile fibre or fabric made from regenerated cellulose (viscose)
Lift or move to a higher position or level.
Elevated to a higher position or level; lifted.
A thing that increases the amount, level, or strength of something.
A partially dried grape.
British sovereignty in India.
An Indian king or prince.
An Indian king or prince.
(in Vedanta) the element or mode of prakriti associated with passion, energy, and movement.
A member of a Hindu military caste claiming Kshatriya descent.
An implement consisting of a pole with a toothed crossbar or fine tines at the end, used especially for drawing together cut grass or smoothing loose soil or gravel.
Behaviour or habits characteristic of a rake; debauchery, dissoluteness, profligacy, promiscuity; an instance of this.
A strong alcoholic spirit made in eastern Europe or the Middle East.
Having or displaying a dashing, jaunty, or slightly disreputable quality or appearance.
A kind of lead-glazed Japanese earthenware, used especially for the tea ceremony.
An abnormal rattling sound heard when examining unhealthy lungs with a stethoscope.
(of troops) come together again in order to continue fighting after a defeat or dispersion.
Vomit.
An uncastrated male sheep.
The hero of the Ramayana, husband of Sita. He is the Hindu model of the ideal man, the seventh incarnation of Vishnu, and is widely venerated, by some sects as the supreme god.
An arbour or porch.
The branches of a tree; trees collectively.
Especially in cities of eastern Spain:a broad street built on a dry river-bed; specifically (now usually in plural) (the name of) an avenue in central Barcelona.
Walk for pleasure in the countryside.
An exceptionally tough, aggressive man.

=  Ramist .

Originally:an individual member of a clone of plants derived by vegetative reproduction from a single parent plant (ortet) and often (at least initially) remaining physically connected with it. Later also:a member or part of any clonal or modular organism; the basic unit or module of such an organism. Compare  ortet , "genet".
A vegetable fibre noted for its length and toughness.
Form branches or offshoots; branch out.
A philosophical system developed by Ramus, based on a controversial revised version of Aristotelian logic.
A follower of Ramus; an advocate or adherent of the philosophical doctrines of Petrus Ramus.
A type of jet engine in which the air drawn in for combustion is compressed solely by the forward motion of the aircraft.
Small stunted trees or bushes collectively; a thicket.
A quarrel or brawl.
More fully "ramon tree":any of several tropical American trees of the family Moraceae that have foliage and twigs used as fodder for livestock, especially Trophis racemosa and Brosimum alicastrum.
Having branches; branched.
Branched, branching; = "ramose".
A sloping surface joining two different levels, as at the entrance or between floors of a building.
A rod for ramming down the charge of a muzzle-loading firearm.
A game (commonly played as a default round in the game of skat in the event that every player passes) in which jacks are trumps and the player who takes the greatest number of points loses.
The East African plant niger, Guizotia abyssinica (family Asteraceae), as cultivated in South Asia for its edible oil and seeds. Frequently attributive, as "ramtil oil", "ramtil seed", etc.
An arm or branch of a bone, in particular those of the ischium and pubes or of the jawbone.
A Hindu (especially Rajput) prince or raja; specifically a member of the family of Rajput origin which effectively ruled Nepal from 1846 to 1951. Also used as a title.
Originally:a bar or bolt for a door. In later use:a bar or post for supporting a building or other structure; a stay or prop; specifically a wall or pillar of coal supporting the roof of a coal mine.
To search (a place) thoroughly.
A large farm, especially in North America or Australia, where cattle or other animals are bred.
(of foods containing fat or oil) smelling or tasting unpleasant as a result of being old and stale.

A type of (especially French or Spanish) wine having a distinctive rich flavour or bouquet, redolent of nuts, butter, or overripe fruit, produced by oxidation or maderization; wine of this style. Also:the quality of possessing these characteristics, associated with certain strong, fortified, or dessert wines, or cognac.
Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing.
The basic monetary unit of South Africa, equal to 100 cents.
Out celebrating or enjoying oneself.
Sexually aroused or excited.
Made, done, or happening without method or conscious decision.
A prolonged or repeated cry or utterance; a long string of words; a rhyme, a song.
The area of variation between upper and lower limits on a particular scale.
A keeper of a park, forest, or area of countryside.
(of a person) tall and slim with long, slender limbs.
Small stones or gravel given to a hawk, usually to improve its digestion.
A Hindu queen.
A frog of the large family Ranidae, which comprises typical frogs with long hind legs that are used for both leaping and swimming.
Designating the deep lingual artery and vein, which run on each side of the undersurface of the tongue from the back to the tip. In early use also:†designating a sublingual salivary gland (obsolete).
A position in the hierarchy of the armed forces.
A soldier in the ranks; a private.
(of a comment or fact) cause continuing annoyance or resentment.
A piece of Irish verse; a stanza, a quatrain.
A shrew, especially the common shrew, Sorex araneus. Also (perhaps by confusion):any of various small rodents. More fully "ranny-mouse".
A sum of money demanded or paid for the release of a captive.
Speak or shout at length in an angry, impassioned way.

A person who commits rape; a rapist.
A groove, ridge, or seam in an organ or tissue, typically marking the line where two halves fused in the embryo.

Originally:the palm Raphia farinifera, which is native to Madagascar and tropical Africa and is a principal source of the fibre raffia. In later use:(in form Raphia) a genus of tropical African and American palms which are noted for their enormous leaves and are a source of fibre, wax, wine, beads, and other products; (also raphia) any palm of this genus.
Happening in a short time or at a great rate.
In France:a fast intercity train, an express.
With rapidity, at a rapid tempo. Also as adjective:played or performed rapidly.
A thin, light sharp-pointed sword used for thrusting.
The violent seizure of someone's property.
A person who commits rape.
A type of coarse snuff.
Descend a rock face or other near-vertical surface by using a doubled rope coiled around the body and fixed at a higher point; abseil.
A monetary unit in the German-speaking cantons of Switzerland and in Liechtenstein, equal to one hundredth of the Swiss franc.
A person who performs rap music.
Completely fascinated or absorbed by what one is seeing or hearing.
A bird of prey, e.g. an eagle or hawk.
A seizure; a sudden or acute attack, especially of mental illness. Also with distinguishing scientific Latin word, as "raptus melancholicus", "raptus nervorum", etc.
(of an event, situation, or condition) not occurring very often.
Make or become less dense or solid.
Not often; seldom.
Very enthusiastic and eager to do something.
Somewhat rare.
The state or quality of being rare.

Acting or done without careful consideration of the possible consequences; impetuous.

Without careful consideration of the possible consequences; impetuously.
A harsh, grating noise.
A person or thing that scrapes something with or as if with a rasp.
Hoarse or harsh-sounding.

A rectangular pattern of parallel scanning lines followed by the electron beam on a television screen or computer monitor.
A nickname for:a hypothetically average or typical African-American man. [Originally applied jestingly in a number of songs and films, and later with more deliberately offensive intent.].

A rodent that resembles a large mouse, typically having a pointed snout and a long tail. Some kinds have become cosmopolitan and are sometimes responsible for transmitting diseases.
A large New Zealand tree of the myrtle family, with crimson flowers and hard red timber.
Relating to rates or rateable value.
An unpleasant or disliked person.
A (usually white) line or streak down the face of a horse.
A measure, quantity, or frequency, typically one measured against another quantity or measure.

A badger-like mammal with a white or grey back and black underparts, native to Africa and Asia. In Africa it is attracted by the honeyguide bird to bee nests, which it breaks open to gain access to the grubs and honey.
A person who, or a thing which, rates something; (in early use especially) a person who fixes the rate for a tax, wage, etc.
(in Ireland) a strong circular earthen wall forming an enclosure and serving as a fort and residence for a tribal chief.
(of a person or their actions) prompt and eager.
Used to indicate one's preference in a particular matter.
Sign or give formal consent to (a treaty, contract, or agreement), making it officially valid.

In early use (frequently in form ratteen):a kind of coarse twilled woollen fabric, usually with a (curled) nap; a frieze or drugget. Later:(usually in form ratine or ratiné) a plain-woven fabric made of cotton or other material with a loose open weave and rough surface, principally used for hard-wearing outer clothing, furniture covers, etc.
A classification or ranking of someone or something based on a comparative assessment of their quality, standard, or performance.
The quantitative relation between two amounts showing the number of times one value contains or is contained within the other.
A fixed amount of a commodity officially allowed to each person during a time of shortage, as in wartime.
(of a bird) having a flat breastbone without a keel, and so unable to fly.

A system for assisting the take-off of an aircraft or missile in which a (usually detachable) unit of rocket engines is used temporarily to provide additional thrust. Frequently attributive, especially in "RATO unit".
A new shoot or sprout springing from the base of a crop plant, especially sugar cane, after cropping.
The thin jointed stems of a palm, used to make furniture.
Very drunk.

A kind of reedmace (bulrush), Typha orientalis (family Typhaceae), formerly used by Maori as a building material, for thatch, etc. Frequently attributive Also in elliptical use (now historical):a hut built of, or thatched with, this plant.
Cause severe and extensive damage to.
Talk incoherently, as if one were delirious or mad.

A river in southern Asia, one of the headwaters of the River Indus, which rises in the Himalayas in Himachel Pradesh, north-western India, and flows generally south-westwards into Pakistan, where it empties into the River Chenab just north of Multan. That has a long reach.

500 (formerly 480) sheets of paper.
